questions.text: What is a 'prompt' when talking about AI?
questions.trivia: Prompt Engineering is a hot new field which focuses on how we can instruct AI language models.

options.text: An algorithm used to train the AI model.
The output given to the user by the AI model.
The input or question from a user given to the AI model.

questions.text: When do we use prompting?
questions.trivia: The prompt is the instructions to an AI model to complete a specific task.

options.text: When we create the AI models.
When we instruct it to do tasks, such as creating images from text or answer a question.
When we fine-tune AI models to better complete specific tasks.

questions.text: Why are good prompts important?
questions.trivia: Good prompts help to produce clear, specific, and relevant responses from AI language models.

options.text: To increase the speed of the AI.
To get correct and relevant responses.
To get a result we need to ask in the correct way.

questions.text: Which of these tasks can an AI language model help us do?
questions.trivia: AI language models can be used for many different tasks, even some things not directly connected to language.

options.text: Writing emails or essays, summarizing text, translating between languages
Creating code, explaining code, finding bugs in code, reviewing code
Helping us coming up with new ideas

questions.text: What are some dangers and risks we need to be aware of when using language models?
questions.trivia: Language models can sound very confident while making up completely false information. We should also never input confidential data such as code, customer information etc.

options.text: The models will learn from our previous conversations, so if I joke around too much it'll be hard to get serious answers.
The language model will try to convince me to pay for longer and better answers.
Language models sound confident when they make things up, and we should never input confidential data into them.

questions.text: Prompts should be as short and concise as possible, the best is a single sentence.
questions.trivia: It's very important that we provide enough context, instructions and details when we prompt. It's easy to get irrelevant answers.

options.text: True! We should only use the most important words to avoid distracting the language model from it's task.
False! We should be specific with what we want, how we want it done, and provide a lot of context.

questions.text: Which of these prompts is better?
questions.trivia: We want to write specific and clear prompts, defining the format and tone, and giving the model a lot of context.

options.text: Please write an email for me asking the others when we can meet for the next sprint planning.

Act as a project manager. Write a short email asking which day and time is the best for the whole team to meet for the next sprint planning. Include a list of 3 proposed times formatted like this 2023-XX-XX HH:mm. Friendly and casual tone.

questions.text: What are some good strategies for creating better prompts?
questions.trivia: Creating better prompts can involve being explicit, defining the format, and using more context.

options.text: Use general words to not influence the model too much.
Write clear instructions, specify the desired length of the output, provide examples.
Be very polite.

questions.trivia: Providing examples is a good way to direct the output of the model. This kind of prompting is called 'one-shot prompting' or 'few-shot prompting'.
questions.text: What is a good way to get the response from a model to be formatted in a specific way?

options.text: Provide an example.
You can't control the output of the model.

questions.text: What could you try when a language model doesn't respond as you want it to?
questions.trivia: It's true that some things are very hard or impossible for language models, but we need to experiment and improve our prompts to get good answers.

options.text: Try the prompt again. Models give different answers each time.
Many things are simply impossible for language models. If you get bad output you should find the information in other ways.
Experiment with different prompts and refine your input

questions.text: How can we prompt a language model to get more creative answers?
questions.trivia: To give uncommon or more creative answers, or you could ask the model to think step-by-step and brainstorm first.

options.text: Ask the model the same question again.
Ask the model to consider wild possibilities.
Ask the model for uncommon answers.

questions.text: What can happen when we use poorly created prompts?
questions.trivia: Poorly chosen prompts can lead to irrelevant answers which might mislead us.

options.text: We don't get an answer. The model will stop working.
The model will start learning bad behavior.
We might get irrelevant answers.

questions.text: What does 'giving the model time to think' mean?
questions.trivia: Step by step instructions are a common way to give the model time to think and it can reduce reasoning errors.

options.text: Telling the model that you're not in a hurry.
Prompting in a way so the model works out an answer over time.
Giving the model a break from generating outputs after they've processed a lot of data.

questions.text: Which of these prompts are most likely to give a good response?
questions.trivia: Prompts that are clear, specific, and provide adequate context are more likely to yield good responses.

options.text: Sentences with words missing that the model can complete.
Clear, specific prompts with many details.
Instructions written as one long sentence.

questions.text: What is this style of prompting called? 'Give me a list of many ideas for an afterwork. Here are two examples: Play shuffleboard. Chocolate tasting.'
questions.trivia: Few-shot prompting (when we give a few examples) is a very useful technique that we can use to give a specific style, tone or format to the output.

options.text: Few-shot prompting.
List prompting.
Example prompting.

questions.text: How can we avoid hallucinations in language models?
questions.trivia: We can't guarantee that no hallucinations occur, but step-by-step instructions can help.

options.text: Ask the model to provide references.
Tell the model not to lie.
Provide step-by-step instructions to improve reasoning.

questions.text: What are some privacy concerns associated with the use of large language models?
questions.trivia: A few global companies have banned the use of ChatGPT. Samsung as an example had confidential data becoming part of the training data of GPT which made it globally available.

options.text: There are no privacy concerns with large language models.
Large language models can physically invade private spaces.
Large language models can inadvertently generate sensitive information or misuse private data.

questions.text: Why do we want to use delimiters in our prompts?
questions.trivia: Delimiter, such as ```, ####, or tags helps the model process different parts of the prompt and can help prevent prompt injection.

options.text: To add aesthetic value to prompts and make it easier to read for humans.
To provide clear start and end points for the intended response.
To clearly divide different parts of the prompt to the model.

questions.text: Can ChatGPT fact check itself?
questions.trivia: ChatGPT can sometimes discover hallucinations made by itself, but we can't rely on it to verify the accuracy of information.

options.text: Yes, it can verify the accuracy of information.
No, it can only provide information based on its training data.
Yes, it can search the internet for real-time fact checking.

questions.text: What is meant by the 'knowledge cutoff' of a language model, and why is this important to consider when using models like GPT-4?
questions.trivia: The model may still try to provide information after it's cutoff date, but that information is not reliable.

options.text: It refers to the amount of data the model can store.
It refers to the date at which the training data ends, meaning the model isn't aware of events in the world after this point.
It refers to the model's ability to forget outdated information.

questions.text: Why is can it be good to start a prompt with 'Act as a'?

options.text: The model is programmed to always look for a role to take.
It provides context and a role for the model, influencing the style and content of the response.
It improves the model's understanding of the question.

questions.text: How does questions in prompts work in AI language models?
questions.trivia: Language models predict the probability of each possible next chunk of characters, given the 'words' that have come before. Asking a question can often cause more similar questions to be predicted. Special reinforcement learning is used to enable the model to answer questions naturally.

options.text: User input is classified as a question, which makes the model respond in a specific way.
A short second phase of training with instruction focused data is done.
Large language models predicts the next probable chunk of characters which gives natural answers to questions.

questions.text: How can we protect systems we build from prompt injection?
questions.trivia: Prompt injection (or prompt hacking) is hard to protect against, but especially important for public models. Limiting tokens, using delimiters, cleaning user input, and classifying input are common best practices.

options.text: By installing a special firewall.
By limiting the input token limit available for users.
By using delimiters and ensuring we clean user input.
By using language models to classify the input, through for example OpenAIs moderation API.

questions.text: What's an emergent capability in an AI model?
questions.trivia: Emergent capabilities are a hotly discussed topic and some believe it's caused by bad measuring while others see them as a by-product of massive neural network size.

options.text: An ability that an AI gradually masters through supervised training.
Behaviors and abilities that suddenly appear as a byproduct of learning.
An ability to emerge from a dormant state when activated

questions.text: How do tokenization work in the context of language models?
questions.trivia: Tokenization helps with performance in understanding context, semantics, and syntax. Different tokenization is used for coding models than for natural language models.

options.text: It transforms the text into a series of images for processing.
It scrambles the input to test the AI's problem-solving ability.
It breaks down input into commonly appearing chunks that the model can process.

questions.text: Is posting a URL into a query a smart way to reduce token use? What can happen if we paste in a url and ask a model without internet connection to summarize it?
questions.trivia: Training data is often outdated and there's not way for us to ensure the validity of the summary. If we don't have complete control over the training data, it's better to provide the complete text in the input.

options.text: The URL might be part of the training data, in which case we'll receive a correct summary.
The model may hallucinate based on words in the url.

questions.text: Are there any reasons to use smaller language models such as GPT-3 if we have access to GPT-4?
questions.trivia: Despite the advanced capabilities of GPT-4, there could be reasons to use GPT-3, including cost efficiency, speed and computational requirements, and application constraints.

options.text: Yes, GPT-3 is faster and can be more cost-efficient.
No, GPT-4 always outperforms GPT-3.
Yes, because GPT-4 replies with too long answers.

questions.text: Are there any ethical considerations related to discrimination and bias with AI and language models?
questions.trivia: Bias in algorithms can be hard to detect and may reinforce itself over time.

options.text: AI models are free from bias and discrimination because of how they're built, so we can use them to overcome human social biases.
AI has biases and discriminate in the same ways as humans.
The data used to train AI models may cause unpredictable biases that are hard to discover.

questions.text: What's the role of temperature in the GPT models?
questions.trivia: For classification, set temperature to 0, but for more creative tasks higher temperature can be important.

options.text: Temperature regulates the randomness or diversity of the model's outputs.
Temperature influences the length of the model's output.
Temperature is used to manage the model's computational power.

questions.text: What are Chain of Thought and Tree of Thought?
questions.trivia: Chain of Thought involves generating a series of prompts and responses with the AI, while Tree of Thought involves branching prompts to explore different paths.

options.text: They are two types of AI models trained to focus on decision making.
They are prompting techniques that improves model perfomance on complex tasks.
They are methods and processes to help us decide when to use AI.

questions.text: What's the role of open source development within language model development?
questions.trivia: Open Source models based on the LLaMA model (such as newest Orca) rapidly pushes progress with cheaper and shorter training cycles.

options.text: The massive amounts of data and computational power required makes open source projects impossible.
Open source development using smaller models and high quality data sets shows great potential.
Open source projects are slow and expensive which makes it very hard.
